Award.AwardTitle: EEC: NSF Nanoscale Science and Engineering (NSE) Grantees Conference

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the 5th Annual NSF Nanoscale Science and Engineering (NSE) Grantees Conference, a program review and research networking workshop that will highlight the ongoing research and educational activities of the NSF NSE grant programs. The proposed conference will be held at the Westin Arlington Gateway Hotel, Arlington, VA on 5-7 December 2011. The lead academic chair of the meeting will be John R. Regalbuto of the University of South Carolina.

The primary goals for this proposed 3-day conference are to promote dissemination of innovative research progress, to facilitate research partnerships, and to identify future research directions. Oral presentations with question periods, panel discussions, and a poster session are planned as platforms to promote inter-university and academic/industry/government/national-laboratory interactions. These interactions represent a vital step toward the advancement of the goals of the U.S. National Nanotechnology Initiative (NNI) (www.nano.gov) which are to:

1) conduct research and development to realize the full potential of nanoscale science and engineering;
2) develop the skilled workforce and supporting infrastructure needed to advance research and development;
3) better understand the social, ethical, health, and environmental implications of the technology; and,
4) facilitate transfer of the new technologies into commercial products.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Nanoscale Science and Engineering (NSE) Grantees Conference is a program review and research networking workshop that highlights the ongoing research and educational activities of the NSF NSE grant programs. The primary goals for the 2011 conference were to promote dissemination of innovative research progress, to facilitate research partnerships, and to identify futureresearch directions. Oral presentations with question periods, panel discussions, and a poster session were conducted as platforms to promote inter-university and academic/industry/government/national laboratory interactions.

These interactions represent a vital step toward the advancement of the goals of the US National Nanotechnology Initiative which are to:

• conduct research and development to realize the full potential of nanoscale science and engineering;

• develop the skilled workforce and supporting infrastructure needed to advance research and development;

• better understand the social, ethical, health, and environmental implications of the technology; and,

• facilitate transfer of the new technologies into commercial products.  Panel discussions were moderated by NSEC center directors and representatives from industry and national laboratories.

 

The conference was held at the Westin Arlington Gateway Hotel, Arlington, VA on 5-7 December 2011. Overviews and highlights of the presentations were posted to the web (http://www.nseresearch.org/2011/index.htm) prior to the meeting and after the meeting a final version of the documents was distributed as a CD-ROM to serve as the conference proceedings.  The first day focused on Scientific Breakthroughs at the Nanoscale  The Day 1 talks and the posters, which were displayed all three days, represent the scientific merit of this work.  Day 2 featured Education and Centers, with a special celebration of the six graduating NSECs from 2001. The third day focused on Innovation and Responsible Governance of Nanotechnology. Discussions of the educational and governance aspects of nanotechnology constitute the broader impacts of this work.  A total of 34 external oral presentations, 8 NSF presentations, 13 panel discussions, and 39 poster presentations were made over the three day conference.


Last Modified: 04/15/2013
Modified by: John Regalbuto

Discussions of the educational and governance aspects of nanotechnology constitute the broader impacts of this work.
